headline.main: Microsoft and Yahoo Equalize Health Benefits for Gay Employees

docs.abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are the latest companies to join the effort to equalize the cost of health benefits for employees with same-sex partners.
docs.snippet: Microsoft and Yahoo are the latest companies to join the effort to equalize the cost of health benefits for employees with same-sex partners.

docs.lead_paragraph: With open enrollment season in full swing, several big companies have said that they would begin to reimburse gay employees for the extra taxes they pay on health insurance for their significant others. Now, two more technology giants, Microsoft and Yahoo, have decided to join in, starting Jan. 1.

headline.main: Microsoft and Yahoo Equalize Health Benefits for Gay Employees

docs.abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo are the latest companies to join the effort to equalize the cost of health benefits for employees with same-sex partners.
docs.snippet: Microsoft and Yahoo are the latest companies to join the effort to equalize the cost of health benefits for employees with same-sex partners.

docs.lead_paragraph: Paul D. Clement, who has appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, for the government and against, is likely to add one more case — the challenge to the health care overhaul law.

headline.seo: Paul D. Clement’s Latest High-Profile Cases
headline.main: Lawyer Opposing Health Law Is Familiar Face to the Justices
headline.print_headline: Lawyer Opposing Health Law Is Familiar Face to the Justices

docs.abstract: Former solicitor general Paul D Clement has appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, both for the government and against it, and is likely to appear before the court once again this time to challenge the health care reform law; Clement is admired by both his adversaries and colleagues for his impressive resume and his legal acumen, which is why he is often tapped to argue controversial cases; is widely thought of as a potential Supreme Court nominee.
docs.snippet: Paul D. Clement, who has appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, for the government and against, is likely to add one more case — the challenge to the health care overhaul law.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that despite enduring hardships and pessimism about the economy, unemployed Americans were optimistic about landing a job.

headline.seo: Jobless Go Without, but Stay Hopeful, Poll Finds
headline.main: Facing Hardship, Jobless Still Say They Have Hope
headline.print_headline: Facing Hardship, Jobless Still Say They Have Hope

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that unemployed Americans are optimistic about finding a job despite enduring hardships and lingering pessimism about the economy; poll also finds that there is deep unease about unemployment benefits with most people who receive unemployment benefits reporting that the money is not enough to meet their basic needs.
docs.snippet: A New York Times/CBS News poll found that despite enduring hardships and pessimism about the economy, unemployed Americans were optimistic about landing a job.

byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER and ALLISON KOPICKI

docs.lead_paragraph: A reliable financial officer can free a chief executive to focus on other parts of the firm once a company’s revenue reaches a certain point, some C.E.O.’s say.

headline.seo: When Should a Small Business Hire a Chief Financial Officer?
headline.main: When Should a Small Business Hire a Finance Chief?
headline.print_headline: When Should A Small Business Hire a Finance Chief?

docs.abstract: Some chief executives say any company, no matter how small, can benefit from having a financial chief to help organize its finances and track its performance; typically, however, hiring one does not become essential until firms reach tipping point of $10 million to $20 million in revenue.
docs.snippet: A reliable financial officer can free a chief executive to focus on other parts of the firm once a company’s revenue reaches a certain point, some C.E.O.’s say.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- It would be hard for any lawyer to fathom a more riveting caseload than the one Paul D. Clement carried during his seven years in President George W. Bush's Justice Department. As solicitor general for three years and deputy solicitor for four, Mr. Clement appeared before the Supreme Court 49 times, defended the administration's detention of terrorism suspects, fought off challenges to the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law and validated the prosecution of medical marijuana growers in a landmark commerce case.

headline.main: Lawyer Opposing Health Law Is Familiar Face to the Justices

headline.main: Insurers Weigh In on Health Care Law

docs.abstract: America’s Health Insurance Plans, a Washington, D.C., trade group, filed a legal brief opposing crucial provisions of the Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: America’s Health Insurance Plans, a Washington, D.C., trade group, filed a legal brief opposing crucial provisions of the Affordable Care Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health insurance industry is urging the Supreme Court to decide as quickly as it can whether the federal health care law is, in fact, constitutional and to consider what other parts of the law should be struck down if the individual mandate does not pass muster.

headline.main: Insurers Weigh In on Health Care Law
